   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:14.0/24.8/1.2, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:695/112/0.43, ALT / AST:25/34, Alk Phos / T Bili:87/0.6,
   Amylase / Lipase:/24, Differential-Neuts:87.1 %, Lymph:6.5 %, Mono:5.4
   %, Eos:0.7 %, Lactic Acid:2.7 mmol/L, Albumin:3.7 g/dL, LDH:275 IU/L,
   Ca++:8.0 mg/dL, Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:2.6 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   67 yo M with DM, HTN presents following VF-arrest s/p shock x1 with
   conversion to sinus tach and initiated on arctic sun cooling protocol.
   .
   # RHYTHM: pt found in VF arrest this morning, down time was briefly for
   a few minutes. He was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach. He was
   given 100mg IV lidocaine and amiodarone 150mg bolus, currently 1mg/hr.
   Pt with spontaneous movement prior sedation.  He was initiated on artic
   sun protocol at the OSH and transferred here.  Pt unclear h/o ischemia,
   heart failure, LVH, structural heart disease or prior arrhythmia that
   might have caused his VF arrest.
   -- plan to continue cooling protocol
   -- Cardiac Arrest Team consult and recs
   -- EEG with neuro input
   -- initiate sedation with propofol according to cooling protocol
   -- cont amiodarone at 1mg/hr
   -- q6 hour labs and coags per cooling protocol
   -- Head CT to r/o bleed
   -- allow BP to autoregulate with MAPS 60-70
   -- trend CE
   -- TTE
   -- ECG
   -- CXR
   -- will place a-line and CVL
   -- monitor on tele
   -- will consider cath emergently if signs of ischemia, but will hold
   off until patient stablizes.
   -- will need to contact PCP to obtain prior records, including cardiac
   history
   -- [**Hospital1 608**] has AED that shows VF arrest, will try to obtain
   .
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated in the field after being found
   unresponsive and in VF arrest. CXR at OSH showed pulm edema, but no
   other acute abnormality. He was hypoxic on the EMS ride over with desat
   to 94% that improved with suction. Concern for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs pulm edema.
   -- Repeat CXR
   -- sedation according to cooling protocol
   -- a-line and ABG
   .
   # CORONARIES: Unclear cardiac history. CE negative and no prior ECG to
   compare.
   -- will need to obtain more history from family and PCP
   [**Name9 (PRE) **] ASA 325mg
   -- trend CE
   -- consider cath this admission, but will hold off until patient
   stablizes or shows signs of ACS
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with pulm edema at OSH and lower ext edema. Unclear history
   of HF.
   -- monitor I/O, daily weights
   -- repeat CXR
   -- hold on diuresis for now
   -- TTE
   .
   #. Leukocytosis: Pt with WBC 11.9 at OSH. Likely reactive in the
   setting of VF arrest. Pt with +UA, but contaminated with epis. CXR no
   pna at OSH.
   -- repeat UA/Cx
   -- recheck labs and lactate
   -- repeat CXR
   -- monitor fever curve and leukocytosis
   .
   # DM: patient with history of DM.
   - monitor FS q6 and cover with ISS
   .
   # HTN: Pt with history of HTN. Will plan to let patient autoregulate BP
   with goal MAPS 60-70.
   -- hold BP meds for now
   FEN:  NPO
   .
   ACCESS: [**Last Name (LF) 3173**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] place a-line and CVL
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin Sq
   -Bowel regimen prn
   .
   CODE: Presumed full
   .
   COMM: Wife: [**Name2 (NI) 12302**] [**0-0-**]
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2148-1-16**] 04:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2148-1-16**] 06:00 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2148-1-16**] 07:41 PM
   Trauma line - [**2148-1-16**] 08:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM) and hypertension (HTN) who presented to the hospital following a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest. He was intubated in the field and was found to have pulmonary edema on chest X-ray (CXR). The patient's condition is critical, and he is being managed in the intensive care unit (ICU).

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.3°C (97.3°F)
* Heart rate: 57 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 98/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 10 mmHg

The patient has a number of medical conditions, including:

* Pulmonary edema
* Hypoxia
* Cardiac arrest
* Leukocytosis
* Diabetes mellitus
* Hypertension

The patient is receiving various medications, including:

* Furosemide (Lasix) for pulmonary edema
* Insulin for hyperglycemia
* Midazolam (Versed) for sedation
* Fentanyl for pain management
* Cisatracurium for muscle relaxation
* Amiodarone for cardiac arrhythmia

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 19.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 12.6 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 238 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 21 mg/dL
* Glucose: 373 mg/dL

The patient's radiology results are:

* Head CT: negative for acute intracranial hemorrhage or other abnormalities
* Chest X-ray (CXR): showing pulmonary edema

The patient's plan is to continue cooling protocol, cardiac arrest team consult, EEG with neuro input, initiate sedation with propofol, and continue amiodarone at 1mg/hr. The patient will also receive q6 hour labs and coags per cooling protocol, and will have a head CT to rule out bleed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis due to pulmonary edema
* Cardiac arrhythmias or ischemia due to cardiac arrest
* Leukocytosis or sepsis due to infection
* Hyperglycemia or ketoacidosis due to diabetes mellitus
* Hypertensive crisis or cardiac failure due to hypertension
* Pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to immobility

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   67 yo M with DM, HTN presents following VF-arrest s/p shock x1 with
   conversion to sinus tach and initiated on arctic sun cooling protocol.
   .
   # RHYTHM: pt found in VF arrest, down time was brief for a few minutes.
   He was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.   He was started on
   amiodarone and initiated on artic sun cooling.  He reached cooling temp
   at 10pm last night.  No clear h/o ischemia, heart failure, LVH,
   structural heart disease or prior arrhythmia that might have caused his
   VF arrest.  However, given cardiac risk factors pt likely with
   underlying cardiac disease.
   -- plan to continue cooling protocol for 24hrs
   -- Cardiac Arrest Team consult and recs
   -- EEG with neuro input
   -- cont sedation with fentanyl/ mid and cont paralysis with cis
   -- cont amiodarone at 5mg/hr for 18 hrs
   -- q8 hour labs and coags per cooling protocol
   -- allow BP to autoregulate with MAPS 60-70
   -- trend CE
   -- TTE
   -- ECG
   -- CXR
   -- monitor on tele
   -- will consider cath emergently if signs of ischemia, but will hold
   off until patient stablizes.
   -- will need to contact PCP to obtain prior records, including cardiac
   history
   -- [**Hospital1 608**] has AED that shows VF arrest, will try to obtain
   .
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated in the field after being found
   unresponsive and in VF arrest. CXR showed diffuse pulm edema.  Pt
   ventilation improved with sedation and paralysis and have been able to
   wean O2/PEEP overnight. Pt diuresed overnight with 40mg IV lasix.
   -- Repeat CXR this AM
   -- cont sedation and paralysis
   -- goal PCO2 35-40 per arrest protocol
   -- ABG q6
   -- I/O goal: -1-1.5L, consider initiation of lasix gtt
   .
   # CORONARIES: Unclear cardiac history. CE initially negative, but
   slowly trending up with Trop 0.43, CK: 695 MB 112, MBI 16.1.  Unlikely
   acute thrombotic event and likely CE elevation in the setting of VF and
   shock.
   -- ASA 325mg and lipitor 80mg daily
   -- trend CE
   -- Will discuss with team regarding initiation of heparin gtt
   -- consider cath this admission, but will hold off until patient
   stablizes or shows signs of ACS
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with pulm edema and lower ext edema. No prior history of HF.
   -- monitor I/O, daily weights
   -- I/O goal 1-1.5L, consider lasix gtt
   -- TTE
   .
   # DM: Pt with elevated glucose in the setting of cooling. patient with
   history of DM on oral medications at home.  Initiated on insulin gtt
   overnight
   - cont insulin gtt and wean after cooling protocol
   - hold home regimen
   .
   # HTN: Pt with history of HTN. Will plan to let patient autoregulate BP
   with goal MAPS 60-70.
   -- hold BP meds for now
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Plts 126 down from 238 on admission. Cooling can
   cause thrombocytopenia. Pre-test is intermediate for HIT.
   -- cont to trend platelets
   -- hold on heparin products for now
   -- send HIT antibodies
   -- will discuss with cardiac arrest team regarding expected
   thrombocytopenia.
   .
   FEN:  NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, RIJ, a-line
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots, hold on heparin products
   -Bowel regimen prn
   .
   CODE:  FULL
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU following a cardiac arrest in the field. He was intubated and received invasive ventilation, and his initial cardiac rhythm was ventricular fibrillation (VF) which converted to sinus tachycardia after being shocked.

The patient's condition has been stable overnight, with improved ventilation and diuresis. His blood glucose levels have been elevated, and he was started on insulin gtt to manage hyperglycemia.

The patient's cardiac status is a concern, with elevated troponin levels and a possible cardiac etiology for his VF arrest. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, which may have contributed to his cardiac condition.

The patient's respiratory status is also a concern, with diffuse pulmonary edema on CXR and the need for ongoing ventilation and oxygen therapy.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of cardiac injury, with elevated troponin, CK, and CKMB levels. His platelet count is low, and he has been started on prophylactic heparin and aspirin to prevent thrombotic events.

The patient's medical history includes diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, and he has a family history of type 2 diabetes and myocardial infarction.

The patient's current medications include amiodarone, fentanyl, midazolam, and insulin, and he is receiving prophylactic antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is a concern, and he may be at risk for further cardiac events, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or acute coronary syndrome.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is also a concern, and he may be at risk for further respiratory deterioration, such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or respiratory failure.
3. Infectious complications: The patient is at risk for nosocomial infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI), and central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI).
4. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's low platelet count and need for anticoagulation therapy may increase his risk for bleeding complications, such as hemorrhagic stroke, gastrointestinal bleeding, or retroperitoneal bleeding.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient's hyperglycemia and need for insulin therapy may increase his risk for hypoglycemia, and his elevated creatinine levels may indicate kidney dysfunction.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male who presented with ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest, was resuscitated, and is currently intubated and sedated in the intensive care unit (ICU).

The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HTN), and is on oral hypoglycemic and lipid-lowering medications. He was found in VF arrest and was resuscitated with cardioversion and amiodarone.

The patient has undergone various interventions, including:

* Invasive ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 34 cmH2O and a plateau pressure of 27 cmH2O
* Sedation with fentanyl and midazolam
* Paralysis with cisatracurium
* Cooling protocol with Arctic Sun
* Cardioversion with amiodarone
* Initiation of insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
* Diuresis with furosemide (Lasix) 40mg IV

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 33.2°C (91.8°F)
* Heart rate: 57 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 98/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 inspirations per minute (ipm)
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 19.1 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 12.6 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 126 x 10^9/L
* Creatine kinase (CK): 695 IU/L
* Troponin-T: 0.43 ng/mL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 21 mmol/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.0 mg/dL
* Glucose: 422 mg/dL

The patient's current medical condition is:

* Cardiac arrest with VF, likely secondary to underlying cardiac disease
* Respiratory failure with diffuse pulmonary edema
* Hyperglycemia with insulin-dependent diabetes
* Hypertension
* Thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 126 x 10^9/L

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation
* Respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Hyperglycemic hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome (HHNS) or diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
* Hypertensive crisis
* Thrombocytopenia, including heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)
* Cardiovascular complications, such as acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or cardiac tamponade

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and cardiac rhythm, as well as to optimize his respiratory and cardiovascular support. Further evaluation and management of his underlying cardiac disease, hyperglycemia, and thrombocytopenia are also necessary to prevent potential complications and improve his overall prognosis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and on oral medications at home. He presented to the hospital following a cardiac arrest, with conversion to sinus tachycardia after being shocked once. He was intubated in the field and received Arctic Sun cooling therapy, which he completed at 10 pm last night.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated, with improved ventilation after sedation and paralysis. CXR shows diffuse pulmonary edema.
* Cardiac: Unclear cardiac history, with non-specific ECG changes. Trop T 0.43, CK 695 MB, and MBI 16.1, suggesting possible NSTEMI. Initiated on heparin gtt, Plavix 600mg x1, ASA 325mg, and Lipitor 80mg daily.
* Hemodynamics: MAP 60-70, with goal to autoregulate BP. Trending CE, with Trop T 0.43, CK 695 MB, and MBI 16.1.
* Neuro: EEG with neuro input planned.
* Metabolic: Elevated glucose, with history of DM on oral medications at home. Initiated on insulin gtt overnight and will continue to wean after cooling protocol.
* Hematology: Thrombocytopenia, with platelet count 126 down from 238 on admission. Pre-test is intermediate for HIT.
* Other: Pneumoboots for DVT prophylaxis, and bowel regimen prn.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: Given the patient's history of VF arrest and unclear cardiac history, there is a risk of recurrent cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but there is a risk of further deterioration due to pulmonary edema and possible aspiration.
3. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and possible aspiration may increase the risk of sepsis.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's history of VF arrest and unclear cardiac history may increase the risk of neurological complications, such as stroke or encephalopathy.
5. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and possible HIT may increase the risk of hemorrhagic complications.
6. Infection: The patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status may increase the risk of infection.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan should be implemented:

1. Continue cooling protocol for 18 hours.
2. Monitor cardiac rhythm and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Continue respiratory support and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
4. Monitor glucose levels and adjust insulin gtt as necessary.
5. Monitor platelet count and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Continue DVT prophylaxis and bowel regimen prn.
7. Consider emergent catheterization if signs of ischemia or cardiac instability develop.
8. Obtain prior cardiac history and records from the patient's primary care physician.

ed yesterday per EP recs [**2-27**] QT prolongation.  He was

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HTN), and coronary artery disease (CAD). He presented with ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and was successfully resuscitated. He was found to have mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and mild regional and global systolic dysfunction.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiovascular: He is receiving heparin, aspirin, and lisinopril for CAD. His cardiac enzymes are elevated, and he has a peak MB at 156. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a prolonged QTc interval, and he is receiving amiodarone for this reason.
* Respiratory: He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory failure. His chest X-ray shows diffuse inflammation, which may be due to aspiration pneumonitis or pulmonary edema.
* Neurological: He is sedated and has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 10. He is responding to verbal stimuli and has some movement.
* Hemodynamic: He is receiving vasopressors for hypotension and has a mean arterial pressure (MAP) goal of 60.
* Renal: He is receiving diuretics for fluid overload and has a creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL.
* Endocrine: He is receiving insulin for tight glycemic control.
* Thrombocytopenia: His platelet count is 126, which is down from 238 on admission.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's CAD and prolonged QTc interval increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias and further cardiac events.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's acute respiratory failure and diffuse inflammation on chest X-ray increase his risk of developing respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and GCS of 10 increase his risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures or brain herniation.
4. Renal complications: The patient's fluid overload and diuretic therapy increase his risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD).
5. Endocrine complications: The patient's DM and insulin therapy increase his risk of developing hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia increases his risk of bleeding and thrombotic complications.

In summary, the patient is a high-risk patient who requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications. He requires ongoing cardiovascular, respiratory, and neurological support, as well as close monitoring of his renal and endocrine function.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 72-inch tall, 126.2 kg male who was admitted with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), unstable angina, and coronary ischemia. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus (DM), type II, and is currently receiving treatment in the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure of 102/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure of 28 cmH2O and a plateau pressure of 27 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating myocardial injury, and an elevated creatine kinase (CK) level, indicating muscle damage. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's imaging studies show mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and mild regional and global systolic dysfunction. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a prolonged QTc interval, which is a concern for torsades de pointes.

The patient's medication list includes anticoagulation therapy with heparin, beta-blockers, and diuretics. The patient is also receiving insulin infusion for glycemic control.

The patient's plan of care includes continued mechanical ventilation, anticoagulation therapy, and monitoring of the patient's cardiac function. The patient will also require ongoing management of their diabetes and hypertension.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation and the presence of a central line.
2. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for developing pneumonia due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation and the presence of a central line.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's prolonged QTc interval and history of cardiac arrest make them at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Myocardial infarction: The patient's elevated troponin-T levels and history of cardiac arrest make them at risk for developing myocardial infarction.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's prolonged use of mechanical ventilation and the presence of a central line make them at risk for developing respiratory failure.
6. Sepsis: The patient's prolonged use of mechanical ventilation and the presence of a central line make them at risk for developing sepsis.
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's prolonged use of mechanical ventilation and the presence of a central line make them at risk for developing DVT.

In conclusion, the patient is a high-risk patient who requires close monitoring and management in the ICU. The patient's potential medical complications include VAP, pneumonia, cardiac arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, respiratory failure, sepsis, and DVT.

   67 yo M with DM, HTN presents following VF-arrest s/p shock x1 with
   conversion to sinus. S/p cooling protocol.
   # RHYTHM/ s/p ARREST: VF arrest, down time reportedly few minutes. He
   was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.  S/p cooling protocol.
   Amiodarone d/c
ed yesterday per EP recs [**2-27**] QT prolongation.  He was
   re-warmed last night.  No clear h/o ischemia, heart failure, LVH,
   structural heart disease or prior arrhythmia that might have caused his
   VF arrest.  However, given extensive CAD risk factors, CAD may have
   been the trigger.
   -- degree of consciousness last night re-assuring in terms of
   neurologic recovery
   -- epilepsy service, SCD consult team, and EP continuing to follow
   -- cont sedation with fentanyl/ mid; off paralytics
   -- allow BP to autoregulate with MAPS 60-70
   -- monitor on tele
   --cath as below, if no reversible ischemic causes, would pursue ICD
   .
   # CORONARIES/ NSTEMI: MB with peak at 156 (CK 736), not definitively
   outside of the range of what could be seen without CAD in setting of
   arrest/shocks. Echo without signifivcant foacl wall mtn abmnl. That
   said, ischemia most likely trigger for VFIB arrest given risk factors.
   -- continue heparin gtt, ASA, lipitor 80. Initiate plavix once ileus
   improved
   -- CE have peaked
   -- cath today
   .
   #. Respiratory Failure: CXR appearance c/w diffuse inflammation
   (possible aspiration pneumonitis) vs pulmonary edema in setting of
   acutely depressef LVEF. Although likely too early for aspiration event
   in seeting of arrest to cause PNA, began broad spectrum Abx
   (cefepime/vanco) on [**1-17**].  Diuresis failed to bolus yesterday. Drip
   lasix started after pt re-warmed with subsequent success in weaning of
   PEEP.  Given degree of interactiveness last night, suspect that pt will
   be quich wean off vent in the pm s/p cath and further diuresis.
   -- serial CXR
   -- cont sedation until s/p cath, then wean with transition to PSV
   -- goal PCO2 35-40 per arrest protocol; serial ABG
   -- I/O goal: -1-1.5L
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with significant pulm edema; No prior history of HF. Fairly
   non-focal distribution (apical predisposition) to hypokinesis with EF
   35-40%. Suspect that this is acutely depressed (partially [**2-27**] stunning)
   in setting of arrest and potentially reversible.
   -- should initiate beta-blocker and ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] as soon as pressor
   weaned
current hypotension may be largely secondary to sedation.
   -- I/O goal 1-1.5L
   # DM: Resumed Insulin drip for tight control. After vent wean, could
   transition to SSI
   -- hold home regimen
   .
   # HTN: Pt with history of HTN. Currently on levophed since yesterday.
   MAP goal 60
   -- hold BP meds for now
   -- wean levophed
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Plts 126 down from 238 on admission. Cooling can
   cause thrombocytopenia. Pre-test is intermediate for HIT. Improved.
   -- cont to trend platelets
    .
   FEN:  NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, RIJ, a-line
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin drip
   -Bowel regimen prn
   .

   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 67-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and coronary artery disease, presented to the emergency department following a cardiac arrest with ventricular fibrillation (VF). He was resuscitated and cooled to 37°C overnight. The patient's initial electrocardiogram (ECG) showed prolonged QTc and bradycardia, prompting the discontinuation of amiodarone.

The patient's condition has been stable overnight, with continued sedation and mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, blood pressure of 102/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. He is receiving heparin, midazolam, fentanyl, and lasix infusions.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 15.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 12.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 126 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.91 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 2.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.7 g/dL
* LDH: 275 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.7 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Transthoracic echocardiogram: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and mild regional and global systolic dysfunction. Mild mitral regurgitation.
* Computed tomography (CT) head: No change since admission, with no hypodensity to suggest evolving infarction.

The patient's medical conditions include acute coronary syndrome (ACS), diabetes mellitus type II, respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and thrombocytopenia. He is receiving treatment for these conditions, including heparin, aspirin, and insulin infusions.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Reversible ischemic causes: The patient's electrocardiogram shows prolonged QTc and bradycardia, which may be reversible. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of these findings.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and prolonged QTc increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he develops pneumonia or other complications.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, including pneumonia and sepsis, given his respiratory failure and immunosuppressed state.
6. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is unstable, which may increase the risk of cardiac complications.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Consider further evaluation of the patient's cardiac condition, including a cardiac catheterization, to determine the cause of his cardiac arrest and to assess the severity of his coronary artery disease.
3. Continue treatment for the patient's respiratory failure, including mechanical ventilation and diuresis.
4. Monitor the patient's platelet count and consider platelet transfusions if necessary.
5. Continue treatment for the patient's diabetes mellitus, including insulin infusions and tight glycemic control.
6. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider adjusting his medications to maintain a blood pressure of 60-70 mmHg.
7. Consider further evaluation of the patient's thrombocytopenia, including a bone marrow biopsy, to determine the cause of this condition.

I recommend that the patient continue to receive close monitoring and treatment in the ICU to manage his complex medical conditions and potential complications.

ed per EP recs [**2-27**] QT prolongation.  No clear h/o

   -- neurologic status at this time very encouraging.

suggesting possible prior CHF. That said, ischemia most

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a VF/VT arrest. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease (CAD). His current conditions include acute coronary syndrome (ACS), unstable angina, coronary ischemia, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest. He was treated with cooling protocol, amiodarone, and metoprolol, and his neurological status is encouraging. He is currently on insulin drip for tight glucose control, and his platelet count is improving.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ischemic heart disease: Given the patient's CAD risk factors and history of VF/VT arrest, there is a high likelihood of ongoing ischemic heart disease.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, or respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of VF/VT arrest and coronary ischemia increases the risk of further cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is decreasing, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as cardiac failure, renal failure, or stroke.
6. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's diabetes may worsen if not managed properly, leading to diabetic ketoacidosis, a life-threatening condition.
7. Infection: The patient's respiratory failure and cardiac arrest increase the risk of infection, including pneumonia, sepsis, or urinary tract infections.
8. Organ dysfunction: The patient's cardiac arrest and respiratory failure may lead to organ dysfunction, including kidney failure, liver failure, or neurological damage.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and arrhythmias, and adjust therapy as necessary.
2. Manage the patient's respiratory failure with aggressive respiratory support and diuresis, as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent bleeding complications.
4. Manage the patient's hypertension with aggressive antihypertensive therapy and monitor for signs of cardiac failure, renal failure, or stroke.
5. Continue to manage the patient's diabetes with insulin drip and monitor for signs of diabetic ketoacidosis.
6. Monitor the patient for signs of infection, including fever, leukocytosis, or changes in mental status.
7. Consider consultation with a cardiologist or intensivist to optimize the patient's care and management.

 ACUTE CORONARY SYNDROME (ACS, UNSTABLE ANGINA, CORONARY ISCHEMIA)
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
 CARDIAC ARREST
   67 yo M with DM, HTN presents following VF-arrest s/p shock x1 with
   conversion to sinus. S/p cooling protocol.
   # RHYTHM/ s/p ARREST: VF arrest, down time reportedly few minutes. He
   was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.  S/p cooling protocol.
   Amiodarone d/c
ed per EP recs [**2-27**] QT prolongation.  No clear h/o
   ischemia, heart failure, LVH, structural heart disease or prior
   arrhythmia that might have caused his VF arrest.  However, given
   extensive CAD risk factors, CAD may have been the trigger.
   -- neurologic status at this time very encouraging.
   -- epilepsy service, SCD consult team, and EP continuing to follow
   -- will see if okay with neuro to d/c EEG monitoring.
   -- monitor on tele
   -- cath as below, if no reversible ischemic causes, would pursue ICD
   -- will start metoprolol 25mg PO BID
   .
   # CORONARIES/ NSTEMI: MB with peak at 156 (CK 736), not definitively
   outside of the range of what could be seen without CAD in setting of
   arrest/shocks. Echo suggestive of diffuse CAD vs LAD distribution;
   degree of cardiac enzymes not high enough to explain this degree of
   injury to LV
suggesting possible prior CHF. That said, ischemia most
   likely trigger for VFIB arrest given risk factors.  This am complains
   of CP.  EKG unchanged.  Possibly MSK secondary to CPR
   -- continue heparin gtt until cath, ASA, lipitor 80, plavix 75
   -- CE have peaked
   -- cath early next week
   .
   #. Hypoxia: Respiratory status improving.  Most likely secondary to
   pulmonary edema.  s/p extubation today.  Feel less likely to be related
   to aspiration PNA or other infectious etiology, but pt continues to
   have thick sputum.  Very unlikely to be [**2-27**] resistant organism.
   -- d/c vanco & cefepime.  Start levofloxacin to complete a 8 day
   course.  (day 1=[**1-17**])
   -- attempt diuresis today if BP allows.  Goal I/O 1L neg.
   -- fup sputum Cx
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with significant pulm edema; No prior known history of HF.
   Fairly non-focal distribution (apical predisposition) to hypokinesis
   with EF 35-40%. Suspect that this is acutely depressed (partially [**2-27**]
   stunning) in setting of arrest and potentially reversible.
   -- start metoprolol as above
   -- start lisinopril at 5mg po daily
   -- I/O goal 1L
   .
   # DM: d/c insulin gtt.  Pt got total of 75 units of regular over past
   24 hrs.  Start lantus at 20 this and convert to sliding scale.
   -- monitor FS, diabetic diet.
   .
   # HTN: Hypotension resolved with IVF bolus x2 yesterday.  Pt off
   pressors  Pt with history of HTN.
   -- restart metoprolol and lisinopril as above.
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Plts 126 down from 238 on admission. Cooling can
   cause thrombocytopenia. Pre-test is intermediate for HIT. Improved.
   -- cont to trend platelets
    .
   FEN:  swallow appears intact per nurse.  Advance diet to cardiac
   heart/healthy & DM.
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, RIJ, a-line
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin drip
   -Bowel regimen prn
   CODE:  FULL, confirmed
   .
   COMM: Wife: [**Name2 (NI) 12302**] [**0-0-**]; family spends night in [**Hospital Ward Name **] 6 solarium
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2148-1-16**] 06:00 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2148-1-16**] 07:41 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2148-1-18**] 08:26 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: (Systemic anticoagulation: Heparin gtt)
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds , Family
   meeting held  Comments:

   Disposition:ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HTN), and coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest. The patient was successfully resuscitated and was intubated for respiratory support. He was diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), unstable angina, and coronary ischemia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient's respiratory status is improving, with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 24 and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, with a peak troponin-T of 1.12 and a peak creatine kinase (CK) of 736. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows signs of diffuse CAD, with a peak at 156.
* Neurological status: The patient's neurological status is encouraging, with no clear signs of ischemia or heart failure.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is 152/69 mmHg, and his heart rate is 80 beats per minute (bpm).
* Laboratory results: The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatine kinase (CK), troponin-T, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he is still intubated and may require continued respiratory support.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, and he may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and presence of a central line may increase his risk for sepsis.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and he may be at risk for bleeding or hemorrhage.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's insulin dose has been adjusted, and he may be at risk for hypoglycemia.
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and he may be at risk for hypertension-related complications.
7. Pulmonary edema: The patient's pulmonary edema is improving, but he may still be at risk for pulmonary edema-related complications.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Continuous monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results
* Adjustments to his insulin and blood pressure medications as needed
* Continuation of his respiratory support and cardiac medications
* Monitoring of his platelet count and bleeding risk
* Follow-up with the cardiology team for further management of his cardiac condition.

 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II

 CARDIAC ARREST
   67 yo M with DM, HTN presents following VF-arrest s/p shock x1 with
   conversion to sinus. S/p cooling protocol.
   # RHYTHM/ s/p ARREST: VF arrest, down time reportedly few minutes. He
   was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.  S/p cooling protocol.
   Amiodarone d/c
ed yesterday per EP recs [**2-27**] QT prolongation.  He was
   re-warmed last night.  No clear h/o ischemia, heart failure, LVH,
   structural heart disease or prior arrhythmia that might have caused his
   VF arrest.  However, given extensive CAD risk factors, CAD may have
   been the trigger.
   -- degree of consciousness last night re-assuring in terms of
   neurologic recovery
   -- epilepsy service, SCD consult team, and EP continuing to follow
   -- cont sedation with fentanyl/ mid; off paralytics
   -- monitor on tele
   --cath as below, if no reversible ischemic causes, would pursue ICD
   .
   # CORONARIES/ NSTEMI: MB with peak at 156 (CK 736), not definitively
   outside of the range of what could be seen without CAD in setting of
   arrest/shocks. Echo suggestive of diffuse CAD vs LAD distribution;
   degree of cardiac enzymes not high enough to explain this degree of
   injury to LV
suggesting possible prior CHF. That said, ischemia most
   likely trigger for VFIB arrest given risk factors.
   -- continue heparin gtt, ASA, lipitor 80. Initiate plavix once ileus
   improved
   -- CE have peaked
   -- cath early nxt week s/p extubation & consent
   .
   #. Respiratory Failure: CXR appearance c/w diffuse inflammation
   (possible aspiration pneumonitis) vs pulmonary edema in setting of
   acutely depressed LVEF. Although likely too early for aspiration event
   in setting of arrest to cause PNA, began broad spectrum Abx
   (cefepime/vanco) on [**1-17**].  Diuresis failed to bolus yesterday. Drip
   lasix started after pt re-warmed with subsequent success in weaning of
   PEEP.  Given degree of interactiveness last night, suspect that pt will
   be quickly wean off vent in the pm s/p cath and further diuresis.
   -- serial CXR
   -- wean with transition to PSV
   -- goal PCO2 35-40 per arrest protocol; serial ABG
   -- I/O goal even until levophed weaned; pulm edema most likely
   cardiogenic although pneumonitis and asp PNA a concern
   -- sputum Cx
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with significant pulm edema; No prior known history of HF.
   Fairly non-focal distribution (apical predisposition) to hypokinesis
   with EF 35-40%. Suspect that this is acutely depressed (partially [**2-27**]
   stunning) in setting of arrest and potentially reversible.
   -- should initiate beta-blocker and ACE/[**Last Name (un) **] when pressor weaned
   -- current hypotension may be largely secondary to sedation vs
   cardiogenic source; distributive shock less likely.
   -- I/O goal 1-1.5L
   .
   # DM: Resumed Insulin drip for tight control. After vent wean, could
   transition to SSI
   -- hold home regimen
   .
   # HTN: Pt with history of HTN. Currently on levophed since yesterday.
   MAP goal 60
   -- hold BP meds for now
   -- wean levophed
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Plts 126 down from 238 on admission. Cooling can
   cause thrombocytopenia. Pre-test is intermediate for HIT. Improved.
   -- cont to trend platelets
    .
   FEN:  NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, RIJ, a-line
   .

   -Bowel regimen prn

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and coronary artery disease (CAD). He presented with a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and was successfully resuscitated. The patient was found to have a diffuse coronary artery disease (CAD) with a peak troponin level of 156 and an echocardiogram showing a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 35-40%.

The patient was aggressively weaned from the ventilator and was extubated at 5 am. He was noted to be hypertensive and mildly tachycardic on the ventilator, and was given lopressor 5mg IV to control his blood pressure. He received 40mg of lasix IV prior to extubation.

The patient's laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 12.7, hemoglobin of 11.0 g/dL, platelet count of 164, and a creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL. His blood cultures were pending, and his urine culture showed a preliminary result of respiratory culture.

The patient was diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), diabetes mellitus, type II, and respiratory failure. He was started on heparin, aspirin, and lipitor, and was scheduled for a cardiac catheterization (cath) early next week.

The patient's respiratory status was stable, with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 98%. His blood pressure was 152/69 mmHg, and his heart rate was 80 beats per minute.

The patient's neurological status was stable, with a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) of 15. His blood glucose level was 143 mg/dL, and his electrolyte levels were within normal limits.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and ACS puts him at risk for further cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction, heart failure, or arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure and diffuse pulmonary edema may lead to further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's history of VF arrest and cardiac arrest may lead to neurological complications, such as stroke, seizures, or cognitive impairment.
4. Infection: The patient's respiratory culture showed a preliminary result of respiratory culture, which may indicate an infection.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count was 126, which is low. This may be due to the patient's underlying medical conditions or the use of certain medications.
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure was 152/69 mmHg, which is high. This may lead to further complications, such as heart failure, stroke, or kidney damage.
7. Diabetes: The patient's blood glucose level was 143 mg/dL, which is high. This may lead to further complications, such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic coma.

In summary, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including cardiac, respiratory, neurological, infectious, thrombocytopenic, hypertensive, and diabetic complications. Close monitoring and management of these complications will be necessary to ensure the patient's optimal care and outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HTN), and coronary artery disease (CAD). He presented to the hospital after a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest, which was successfully treated with a single shock. He was subsequently cooled and has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management.

The patient's current medications include metoprolol 25mg PO BID, lisinopril 5mg daily, and aspirin. He is also receiving heparin drips for prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer prophylaxis with an H2 blocker.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 77 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 106/57 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 95% on a nasal cannula.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated cardiac enzymes, including troponin-T and creatine kinase (CK), suggesting acute coronary syndrome (ACS). His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows signs of ischemia, including deeper T waves in lead V5 and ST segment changes in leads V2-V3.

The patient's respiratory status is improving, with a reduction in oxygen requirements and improved lung sounds. He is at risk for respiratory failure, but his oxygen saturation is currently within normal limits.

The patient's neurologic status is improving, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15 and a return of spontaneous circulation.

The patient's glucose levels are under control, with a current level of 105 mg/dL. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are within normal limits.

The patient's platelet count is 113,000/mL, which is lower than his admission value of 238,000/mL. He is at risk for bleeding and will require close monitoring.

The patient's medication list includes:

* Metoprolol 25mg PO BID
* Lisinopril 5mg daily
* Aspirin
* Heparin drips for prophylaxis against DVT
* Stress ulcer prophylaxis with an H2 blocker
* Lantus insulin at 20U daily
* Sliding scale insulin

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Cardiac arrest
* Acute coronary syndrome (ACS)
* Respiratory failure
* Neurologic impairment
* Bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
* Infection due to prolonged hospitalization
* Metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia
* Hypotension due to vasopressor withdrawal

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue metoprolol 25mg PO BID
* Continue lisinopril 5mg daily
* Continue heparin drips for prophylaxis against DVT
* Continue stress ulcer prophylaxis with an H2 blocker
* Monitor glucose levels and adjust insulin dosing as needed
* Monitor platelet count and bleeding risk
* Continue to monitor cardiac enzymes and adjust therapy as needed
* Consider cardiac catheterization to evaluate coronary anatomy and function
* Consider implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement for secondary prevention of sudden cardiac death.

   conversion to sinus. S/p cooling protocol.
   # RHYTHM/ s/p ARREST: VF arrest, down time reportedly few minutes. He
   was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.  S/p cooling protocol.
   Amiodarone d/c
ed per EP recs [**2-27**] QT prolongation.  No clear h/o
   ischemia, heart failure, LVH, structural heart disease or prior
   arrhythmia that might have caused his VF arrest.  However, given
   extensive CAD risk factors, CAD may have been the trigger. neurologic
   status continues to improve
   - appreciate EP recs
   -- cont metoprolol 25mg PO BID
   -- monitor on tele
   -- cath as below, if no reversible ischemic causes, would pursue ICD
   .
   #. ARF: Pt with Cr of 1.4 this AM. This was following IV lasix and poor
   po intake.   Pt also started on ACEi.  Possible pre-renal vs b/l
   stenosis.
   - will keep even for now and encourge po intake
   - urine lytes
   - d/c lisinopril
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   - consider renal u/s with dopllers if worsens
   .
   # CORONARIES/ NSTEMI: MB with peak at 156 (CK 736), not definitively
   outside of the range of what could be seen without CAD in setting of
   arrest/shocks. Echo suggestive of diffuse CAD vs LAD distribution;
   degree of cardiac enzymes not high enough to explain this degree of
   injury to LV suggesting possible prior CHF. That said, ischemia most
   likely trigger for VFIB arrest given risk factors.  This am complains
   of CP.  EKG unchanged.  Possibly MSK secondary to CPR
   -- continue heparin gtt until cath, ASA, lipitor 80, plavix 75
   -- CE have peaked
   -- cath early next week
   .
   #. Hypoxia: Respiratory status improving.  Most likely secondary to
   pulmonary edema.  s/p extubation today.  Feel less likely to be related
   to aspiration PNA or other infectious etiology, but pt continues to
   have thick sputum.  Very unlikely to be [**2-27**] resistant organism.
   -- levofloxacin to complete a 8 day course.  (day 1=[**1-17**])
   -- fup sputum Cx
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with significant pulm edema; No prior known history of HF.
   Fairly non-focal distribution (apical predisposition) to hypokinesis
   with EF 35-40%. Suspect that this is acutely depressed (partially [**2-27**]
   stunning) in setting of arrest and potentially reversible.
   -- metoprolol 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   -- I/O goal even for now
   .
   # DM: d/c insulin gtt yesterday.  Started lantus at 20U yesterday and
   sliding scale.
   -- monitor FS, diabetic diet.
   .
   # HTN: Hypotension resolved with IVF bolus x2 yesterday.  Pt off
   pressors  Pt with history of HTN.
   -- restart metoprolol as above.
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Plts 113 down from 238 on admission. Cooling can
   cause thrombocytopenia. Pre-test is intermediate for HIT.
   -- cont to trend platelets
    .
   FEN:  swallow appears intact per nurse.  Advance diet to cardiac
   heart/healthy & DM.
   .

   .

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease, who presented with ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and was successfully resuscitated. He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has been treated with various medications, including metoprolol, lisinopril, and levofloxacin, and has undergone cardiac catheterization.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: temperature 36.6°C, heart rate 77 beats per minute, blood pressure 106/57 mmHg, respiratory rate 27 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation 95%.
* Laboratory results: white blood cell count 8.1 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin 10.9 g/dL, creatinine 1.4 mg/dL, troponin-T 0.88 ng/mL.
* Electrocardiogram: shows a sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 77 beats per minute.
* Physical examination: the patient is alert and oriented, with a soft and distended abdomen, and trace edema in both lower extremities.

Potential medical complications:

* Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with ongoing cardiac ischemia
* Respiratory failure due to pulmonary edema
* Cardiac arrest with potential for further arrhythmias
* Thrombocytopenia with risk of bleeding
* Renal failure with potential for further deterioration
* Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) due to inadequate insulin therapy
* Hypotension due to vasopressor withdrawal
* Pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility and risk factors
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation

Assessment and plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status, including cardiac enzymes and electrocardiogram.
* Continue to treat the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medication dosing accordingly.
* Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
* Monitor the patient's platelet count and consider transfusion if necessary.
* Consider further cardiac catheterization to assess the extent of coronary artery disease.
* Consider placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) if the patient is at high risk for future cardiac arrest.
* Continue to monitor the patient's pulmonary function and consider bronchodilator therapy if necessary.
* Consider further imaging studies, such as computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), to assess the extent of pulmonary edema and potential underlying causes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male who presented with a ventricular fibrillation (V-fib) arrest and subsequent shock. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and extensive coronary artery disease (CAD) risk factors.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he still has thick sputum and is at risk for pulmonary edema.
* Cardiac: The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, indicating possible myocardial infarction (MI). His electrocardiogram (EKG) shows sinus rhythm, and his echocardiogram suggests diffuse CAD.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is elevated at 1.7, and he is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) due to overdiuresis and the addition of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.
* Neurological: The patient's neurological status is improving, but he is still delirious and requires ongoing monitoring.
* Hematological: The patient's platelet count is decreasing, and he is at risk for thrombocytopenia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's thick sputum and respiratory symptoms make him at risk for pneumonia.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine level and potential overdiuresis make him at risk for AKI.
3. Myocardial infarction (MI): The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes and EKG changes suggest possible MI.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's decreasing platelet count and potential heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) make him at risk for bleeding.
5. Pulmonary edema: The patient's respiratory symptoms and elevated creatinine level make him at risk for pulmonary edema.
6. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and risk factors make him at risk for DVT.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Ongoing monitoring of his respiratory, cardiac, and renal status
* Administration of antibiotics to treat possible pneumonia
* Management of his diabetes and hypertension
* Monitoring of his platelet count and potential bleeding risk
* Consideration of a renal ultrasound with Dopplers if his creatinine level worsens
* Further evaluation of his cardiac enzymes and EKG changes to determine the extent of his cardiac injury.

   Assessment and Plan
   67 yo M with DM, HTN presents following VF-arrest s/p shock x1 with
   conversion to sinus. S/p cooling protocol.
   .
   # RHYTHM/ s/p ARREST: VF arrest, He was shocked x1 with conversion to
   sinus tach.  S/p cooling protocol. Amiodarone d/c
ed per EP recs [**2-27**] QT
   prolongation.  No clear h/o ischemia, heart failure, LVH, structural
   heart disease or prior arrhythmia that might have caused his VF
   arrest.  However, given extensive CAD risk factors, CAD may have been
   the trigger. neurologic status wnl.
   - appreciate EP recs
   -- cont metoprolol 25mg PO BID
   -- monitor on tele
   -- cath once renal function improves, if no reversible ischemic causes,
   would pursue ICD
   .
   #. ARF: Pt with Cr of 1.7 this AM.  Most likely secondary to
   overdiuresis and the addition of ACE.  Possible pre-renal vs b/l
   stenosis.  Sediment not suggestive of ATN per renal.
   - repeat U/A
   - will keep even for now
   - renal consult appreciated.
   - renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   - consider renal u/s with dopllers if worsens
   .
   # CORONARIES/ NSTEMI: MB with peak at 156 (CK 736), not definitively
   outside of the range of what could be seen without CAD in setting of
   arrest/shocks. Echo suggestive of diffuse CAD vs LAD distribution;
   degree of cardiac enzymes not high enough to explain this degree of
   injury to LV suggesting possible prior CHF. That said, ischemia most
   likely trigger for VFIB arrest given risk factors.  CP most likely
   musculoskeletal and continues to improve.
   -- continue heparin gtt until cath, ASA, lipitor 80, plavix 75
   -- cath early next week
   .
   #. Hypoxia: Respiratory status improving.  Most likely secondary to
   pulmonary edema.  Sputum with coag positive staph
 will fup
   sensitivities  Very unlikely to be [**2-27**] resistant organism.
   -- vanco 1 gram now & Q12
   -- levofloxacin to complete a 8 day course.  (day 1=[**1-17**])
   -- fup sputum Cx
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with significant pulm edema; No prior known history of HF.
   Fairly non-focal distribution (apical predisposition) to hypokinesis
   with EF 35-40%. Suspect that this is acutely depressed (partially [**2-27**]
   stunning) in setting of arrest and potentially reversible.
   -- metoprolol 25mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   -- I/O goal even for now
   .
   # DM: cont lantus at 20U yesterday and sliding scale.
   -- monitor FS, diabetic diet.
   .
   # HTN: SBP ranges from
   -- metoprolol as above.
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Plts stable, but down from 238 on admission.
   Cooling can cause thrombocytopenia. Pre-test is intermediate for HIT.
   -- cont to trend platelets
    .
   FEN:  cardiac heart/healthy & DM.
   ACCESS: PIV, RIJ
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin drip
   -Bowel regimen prn
   CODE:  FULL, confirmed

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male who presented with a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and was resuscitated. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease (CAD) risk factors. The patient's condition has been complex, with multiple medical issues and interventions.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 81 beats per minute, blood pressure of 101/51 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 95% on nasal cannula. His respiratory status is improving, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a PaO2 of 27 mmHg on a 40% FiO2.

The patient has a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL, indicating acute kidney injury (AKI). His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 27 mg/dL, and his potassium level is 4.7 mmol/L. He has a mild elevation in his troponin level, suggesting possible cardiac injury.

The patient has a history of CAD, and his cardiac enzymes are elevated, consistent with a myocardial infarction (MI). He has a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 35-40%, suggesting possible cardiac stunning or reversible cardiac injury.

The patient's medical team is concerned about the possibility of sepsis, given the patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count. He has a pending blood culture, and his sputum culture grew coagulase-positive Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus).

The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely related to the cooling protocol and may be related to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). His platelet count is stable, but down from his admission value of 238.

The patient's medical team is planning to continue his medications, including metoprolol, heparin, and levofloxacin. They are also planning to perform a cardiac catheterization to assess the patient's coronary arteries and to consider placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD).

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's elevated white blood cell count and pending blood culture, there is a risk of developing sepsis.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and elevated cardiac enzymes suggest a risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's AKI may progress to renal failure if not managed appropriately.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and history of HIT may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Pulmonary edema: The patient's pulmonary edema may worsen if not managed appropriately.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical issues and interventions. His condition is being closely monitored, and his medical team is planning to continue his medications and perform further testing to assess his cardiac and renal function.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male who presented to the ICU after a v-fib arrest. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. His current condition is complicated by acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL, and he is receiving heparin infusions for anticoagulation. He is also experiencing hypoxia, pulmonary edema, and cardiac dysfunction, with an ejection fraction of 35-40%. His platelet count is low, and he is being monitored for thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Further cardiac arrest or arrhythmias due to underlying coronary artery disease and potential for ischemia.
	* Heart failure or cardiogenic shock due to decreased cardiac function.
2. Renal Complications:
	* Progressive AKI or worsening of current condition, potentially leading to dialysis.
	* Fluid overload or electrolyte imbalances due to overdiuresis or inadequate fluid management.
3. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia or respiratory failure due to aspiration or other infectious etiologies.
	* Pulmonary edema or worsening of current condition, potentially leading to respiratory failure.
4. Thrombotic Complications:
	* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility and anticoagulation therapy.
	* Hemorrhagic complications due to thrombocytopenia or anticoagulation therapy.
5. Metabolic Complications:
	* Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia due to diabetes management or other metabolic factors.
	* Electrolyte imbalances or acid-base disorders due to inadequate fluid management or other metabolic factors.
6. Infectious Complications:
	* Sepsis or septic shock due to underlying infections or catheter-related complications.
	* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections due to aspiration or other infectious etiologies.

These potential complications highlight the need for close monitoring and aggressive management of the patient's condition to prevent further deterioration and improve his chances of recovery.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male who presented with a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and subsequent shock. He was converted to sinus rhythm and was started on a cooling protocol. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HTN), and coronary artery disease (CAD) risk factors.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.3°C (99.1°F)
* Heart rate: 72 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 114/45 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 inspirations per minute (ipm)
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 11 mmHg, MAP 65 mmHg

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, no left jugular venous distension (JVD)
* CV: RRR, normal S1/S2, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
* LUNG: Bilateral basilar rhonchi, no wheeze or crackles
* ABDOMEN: Protruberant, soft, + bowel sounds, no rebound tenderness or guarding
* EXTREMITIES: Trace bilateral lower extremity edema, left upper extremity mildly edematous
* PERIPHERAL VASCULAR: Right radial pulse 2+, left radial pulse 2+, right digital pulse 2+, left digital pulse 2+
* SKIN: Ecchymosis over left forearm
* NEUROLOGIC: Awake, alert, oriented, speech fluent, thought process clear, moving extremities freely, sensation grossly intact

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 8.1-7.1 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 10.4-10.3 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 111-112 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.9-1.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 51-53 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na 125-134 mmol/L, K 4.5-4.7 mmol/L, Cl 99-103 mmol/L
* Glucose: 105-153 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* DM
* HTN
* CAD risk factors
* Pulmonary edema
* Hypokinesis with EF 35-40% on echocardiogram
* Thrombocytopenia

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Cardiac failure
* Pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Thrombocytopenia
* Renal failure
* Respiratory failure

The patient is currently receiving treatment for:

* Ventricular fibrillation
* Pneumonia (MSSA)
* Hypertension
* Diabetes mellitus
* Thrombocytopenia
* Pulmonary edema

The patient's plan includes:

* Monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Antibiotic therapy for pneumonia
* Cardiovascular medications for hypertension and CAD risk factors
* Renal dose medications and avoidance of nephrotoxins
* Regular echocardiograms to monitor cardiac function
* Platelet monitoring to assess thrombocytopenia
* Follow-up with renal and cardiology consultants as needed.
